attributes.title: Hasbro Vs. Mattel - Battle Of The Toy Soldiers
summary: Two historic toy companies but with very different business models.
One deserves a spot in your dividend portfolio.
The other may be a melting ice cube.

attributes.content:
Before the invention of iPods, kids played with actual toys, and that industry was (is) dominated by two major players - Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) and Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS).

At first glance, they are both manufacturers of small plastic items designed to provide children with hours of endless joy. Many investors group these two together, not spending the time to evaluate their differences, but simply thinking of them as "old industry" losers in what is now a digital age of children entertainment.

Let's start by understanding the background of each company.

Hasbro

Founded in 1923, Hasbro was originally known as Hassenfeld Brothers after the namesake founders - Henry, Hillel and Herman Hassenfeld. From simple beginnings in Rhode Island as a textile company, Hasbro has grown to become one of the largest global toy manufacturers. Some of their most memorable concepts include Cabbage Patch Kids, G.I. Joe, Furby, Mr. Potato Head and Monopoly.

Mattel

A young company in comparison to Hasbro, Mattel was founded in California in 1945 to sell picture frames and later dollhouse furniture. Mattel struck gold when they introduced the Barbie in 1959 and followed it up with other notable products like Hot Wheels and Fischer-Price baby toys.

Sales Geography

Both companies have a very similar level of total revenue and also the geographic mix - half US/North America and half International.
